TEXT.citation: Early, R. J., & Whitehorn, J. (2003). One hundred Paiwan texts. Pacific Linguistics, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, The Australian National University.
TEXT.BibTeX_citation: @book{100paiwantexts, author = {Robert Early and John Whitehorn}, title = {One Hundred Paiwan Texts}, year = {2003}, publisher = {Pacific Linguistics, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, The Australian National University}}

S.FORM: Kai: "uri keman itjen tu sa qarizang nia su vuvu," ku ayain, kina, a su vuvu ka sauni, ka tsemalivalivat amen ta za su quma.
Kai: "ori keman itjen to sa qarizang nia so vovo," ko ayain, kina, a so vovo ka saoni, ka cemalivalivat amen ta za so qoma.
S.TRANSL: (Rough translation) Kai: “We’ll be eating some of your grandparents’ beans,”I said to your grandchild, mother, earlier on when we were passing your fields.

S.FORM: Kaleskes: inu inu?
Kaleskes: ino ino?
uzi ki mavan aza i kadjalanan a taupuan, aya-u.
ozi ki mavan aza i kadjalanan a taopoan, aya-o.
S.TRANSL: Oh I suppose you mean the one terrace by the roadside.

S.FORM: Kai: pai ła, maya manu benereq a "taupuan" aya ta za nu penulingelingetj ta za nu quma.
Kai: pai lja, maya mano benereq a "taopoan" aya ta za no penolingelingetj ta za no qoma.
S.TRANSL: Kai: Oh come on, don’t joke by saying “one terrace” about your fields all over the place.

S.FORM: Kaleskes: iya, ui, małimałi; nu uri keman itjen kaumaya nu izua.
Kaleskes: iya, oi, maljimalji; no ori keman itjen kaomaya no izoa.
S.TRANSL: Kaleskes: Oh yes, thank you; perhaps we’ll have something to eat if there is any crop.

S.FORM: Kai: ui, qau mayanga za nu puk, mayanga za nu łangga, mayanga za nu łumay, mayanga za nu vaqu.
Kai: oi, qao mayanga za no pok, mayanga za no ljangga, mayanga za no ljomay, mayanga za no vaqo.
S.TRANSL: Kai: Yes, not to mention your peas, your sesame, your banyard millet, your ordinary millet.

S.FORM: uri keman itjen aravats ta za nu kikavetsengel.
ori keman itjen aravac ta za no kikavecengel.
S.TRANSL: We are going to have plenty to eat from your crops.

S.FORM: Kaleskes: ui, łakua qadjaw ki tja kani anga.
Kaleskes: oi, ljakoa qadjaw ki tja kani anga.
S.TRANSL: Kaleskes: Yes, but I don’t know whether we’ll eat any of it,

S.FORM: maya sa qemuzimuzip, maya sa tja kinatsavitsaviłan a nakuya aravats.
maya sa qemozimozip, maya sa tja kinacavicaviljan a nakoya aravac.
S.TRANSL: what with the pests and (making good our losses on) the very bad years.

S.FORM: Kai: qu saka ki tja pinatsunan anga a tsinuvuqan.
Kai: qo saka ki tja pinaconan anga a cinovoqan.
S.TRANSL: Kai: Well, let’s be content to look at the crops.

S.FORM: qau mamaw ka ta zua inika tjen a napatsun anga ta tsinuvuqan(?).
qao mamaw ka ta zoa inika tjen a napacon anga ta cinovoqan(?).
S.TRANSL: It’s not as if we hadn’t any crops to look at.

S.FORM: łakua qemazał a ika tjen a uri sinikuletj na Tsemas, a ika tjen a uri sinipenetj tua tja sikavałut.
ljakoa qemazalj a ika tjen a ori sinikoletj na Cemas, a ika tjen a ori sinipenetj toa tja sikavaljot.
S.TRANSL: Anyway it would be something quite out of the ordinary if God didn’t supply us and arrange for us to have something to live on.
